column4: When UE identity is obtained, it allows attacker to launch other attacks such as geolocation tracking, degradation of service, loss of traffic confidentiality, or physical attack.
Destruction or damage of these assets may cause unavailability of resources
Destruction or damage of these assets may cause information destruction
If network boundaries are breached, monitoring system may detect unusual network flow
Adversary may attempt to discover networks and live hosts on the networks
Adversary may attempt connect to hosts in the target network after profiling hosts and network mapping.

column3: Identifier of some network nodes is known
column4: Adversary now knows identifiers of some network nodes, and so these nodes can now be spoofed or targeted for Denial of Service.

column2: Consume data allocation to deny or degrade service
column4: Sustained degraded communication of legitimate UEs until additional data is purchased.
Network flow compromise can lead to DOS, or change the traffic pattern and paths.  Adversary may change the path for network sniffing or for MiTM activity.
Legitimate subscribers are denied access or existing sessions can be terminated.
Subscriber sessions are redirected to a malicious server.

column3: Identifier of some network nodes revealed
column4: Adversary now knows identifiers of some network nodes, and so these nodes can now be spoofed or targeted for Denial of Service.

column3: A Compromised Image is deployed in production
column4: A compromised image deployed in the production can lead to variety of adversarial activities depending on what capabilities were added/deleted from the image.

column3: UE data unprotected on air interface
column4:
Control Plane: All UE signaling data may be revealed if both NAS and AS CP (RRC) security algorithms are weakened.

User Plane: Subscriber (user plane) data may be revealed if AS UP security algorithms are weakened.

column2: Manipulate Virtual Network Function VNF Configuration
column4: VNF compromise can lead to DOS or change in the traffic pattern and paths.
Network flow compromise can lead to DOS or change the traffic pattern and paths.  Adversary may change the path for network sniffing or for AiTM activity.

column3: Both CP and UP data are eavesdropped or modified
column4: Both UE signaling and normal data communication with network will be impacted.
With the cloned USIM card, adversary now has access to the victim’s permanent identifier (SUPI), master secret key K and operator key (OPc). Those can be used for unauthorized access to 5G network.
Subscriber’s sensitive signaling and user plane data are exposed to the adversary.
Geolocation can make electronic attack for degradation of service more effective, bidding down to defeat ID and traffic confidentiality more effective, and can expose subscriber to physical attack.

column3: Adversary is able to perform crypto operations fraudulenty.
column4: Adversary would have the ability to perform signing and cryptographic operations that would permit the adversary to masquerade as a legitimate authorized user and perform operations against NFs.

column3: UE at risk of data manipulation
column4: UE signaling with network and user plane data may be impacted. This can be used to cause DoS attack.

column3: Network signaling at risk of data manipulation
column4: Network communication within core network or on the non-SBI interfaces or on roaming interface may be impacted.

column3: UE’s location is tracked by rogue NF
column4: Target slice information is leaked, slice confidentiality is breached due to sharing the NF between slices.
Attacker can route command and control traffic through DNS to control botnets or other entities.
Attacker has a route to exfiltrate stolen data disguised as DNS packets.
This involves information such as identifiers, files, user credentials, etc.
No UE in the area where false base station is present can get connection to the network.
Theft of these assets may cause an unavailability of resources.
Theft of these assets may cause an increase in maintenance costs for the operator.
Destruction or damage of these assets may cause an unavailability of resources.
Destruction or damage of these assets may cause information destruction

column3: IMSI/SUPI is available to the adversary
column4: If IMSI/SUPI is obtained, many other subsequent attacks are possible such as retrieving subscriber location, network slice, data network of the UE.
Attacker will be able to route traffic through DNS channels to connect to internet free of charge.
Attacker can route command and control traffic through DNS to control botnets or other entities.
Attacker has a route to exfiltrate stolen data disguised as DNS packets.

column2: Redirection of traffic via user plane network function
column4: If an adversary redirects to their own server, they can access the  subscriber data, who will not be aware that the traffic is being intercepted.

column3: AMF service will not be available to legitimate users during attack.
column4: If AMF services are down, all services for the existing UEs which use NAS layer will not be available. For example: mobility, session management (QoS etc.), PDU session set up / tear down, SMS over NAS, location management. New UE connection attempts will also fail when AMF services are down. Clause 8.2.2.1 of [2].
Core network function is DoS’ed from the user plane.
Legitimate subscribers are not able to connect to 5G network.
Some 5G core network services will be unavailable causing temporary network outage.
Attacker will be able to route traffic through DNS channels to use the network free of charge.
Attacker can route command and control traffic through DNS to control botnets or other entities.
Attacker has a route to exfiltrate stolen data disguised as DNS packets.
Network flow compromise can lead to DOS, or change the traffic pattern and paths.  Adversary may change the path for network sniffing or for MiTM activity.
Allows an adversary to identify UE as target of interest for geolocation, degradation of service, loss of traffic confidentiality, or physical attack.

column3: UE data not integrity protected on air interface
column4:
Control Plane (CP): All UE signaling data may be tampered with if both NAS and AS CP (i.e., RRC) algorithms are weakened. 

User Plane (UP): Subscriber (user) data may be tampered with if AS UP algorithms are weakened.

As a result, subscriber data session does not get setup (DoS attack) or gets interrupted during an active session.
Exposure of subscriber sensitive information such as call/data/text metadata.
Subscriber data session does not get setup (DoS attack) or gets interrupted, spoofed or redirected during an active session.
Adversary affects the radio network configuration, accesses configuration data, and perform other unauthorized activities
Adversary degrades network operation or in the worst case, causes network outage

column3: Sensitive UE data exposed to adversary
column4: UE and subscriber’s sensitive data is revealed to the adversary

column3: SUPI is available to the adversary
column4: If SUPI is obtained, many other subsequent attacks are possible such as subscriber identity spoofing and location tracking.

column2: Fraudulent AMF registration for UE in UDM
column3: Follow on attacks by rogue AMF
column4: A rogue AMF could mount other attacks on the victim UE, but the UE is not currently registered on the network. For example, the AMF can ask the LMF for the location of that UE; this may work if the UE is actually registered to this network, otherwise, it will return the last known location.

When home network is unusual (e.g., US home network in Afghanistan), allows attacker to identify UE as target of interest for geolocation, degradation of service, loss of traffic confidentiality, or physical attack.

column3: Further attacks on subscriber are possible
column4: Further attacks such as physical attack and eavesdropping on subscriber private data are possible once their coarse location is known to the adversary.
Destruction of assets, unauthorized access, theft of data on local storage, vandalism, sabotage
Destruction or damage of these assets may cause information destruction
UE user plane data gets disrupted
Incorrect subscribers' charging records are generated
Adversary affects the radio network configuration, accesses configuration data, and performs other unauthorized activities
Adversary degrades network operation or in the worst case, causes network outage

column3: Sensitive UE data exposed to adversary
column4: UE and subscriber’s sensitive data are revealed to adversary

column3: Temporary loss of subscriber data confidentiality.
column4: Transient technique. Works only as long as adversary is able to retain connection.

column3: Further attacks based on UE’s internet usage
column4: Further attacks are possible on the victim UE based on the data collected, e.g. bank fraud or attacks from social media sites.

column2: Unauthorized access to NEF via token fraud
column4: Adversary has access to network services exposed by NEF
Information about what other services are provided by a given MNO

column2: Base station flood with fictitious access requests
column4: Legitimate UEs have low probability of successfully requesting access

column2: Radio control manipulation via rogue xApps
column4: Adversary degrades network operation or in the worst case causes temporary network outage.

column4: Operator’s network policies are known to the adversary.

column2: Radio control manipulation via rogue xApps

column3: UE coarse location is known to adversary
column4: Adversary knows the cellular base station area where the UE is located. Further attacks are possible such as eavesdropping on target UE’s communication to network if UE coarse location is known to adversary.
Destruction or damage of these assets may cause an unavailability of resources.
Destruction or damage of these assets may cause information destruction.

column2: Trigger Fraud Alert to Deny Service
column4: Denial of service continues until service provider is convinced there is no fraud.

column3: UE data unprotected on network interfaces
column4:
Control Plane: All UE signaling data may be revealed if IPSec and TLS are disabled.

User Plane: Subscriber (user plane) data may be revealed if IPSec is disabled. 

UE CP & UP data can be sniffed, see FGT1040 – Network Sniffing

column3: UE is connected to a 4G network
column4: UE is now vulnerable to 4G threats.
UE is subject to further attacks such as malware insertion, RPC execution etc.

column3: Temporary loss of subscriber data confidentiality or integrity.
column4: Transient technique; works only as long as adversary-in-the-middle is able to retain connection.
IP addresses of core network functions known
Geolocation can make electronic attack for degradation of service more effective, bidding down to defeat ID and traffic confidentiality more effective, and can expose subscriber to physical attack.
Now the adversary knows the SD of a given slice it is not authorized to contact.
